citing_paper_authors: Ran, Tian | Yusuke, Miyao | Takuya, Matsuzaki
raw_text: for almost all pairs (Bos and Markert, 2005)
clean_text: However, this method does not work for realworld datasets such as PASCAL RTE (Dagan et al., 2006), because of the knowledge bottleneck: it is often the case that the lack of sufficient linguistic knowledge causes failure of inference, thus the system outputs "no entailment" for almost all pairs (Bos and Markert, 2005).

citing_paper_authors: Ran, Tian | Yusuke, Miyao | Takuya, Matsuzaki
raw_text: On PASCAL RTE datasets, strict logical inference is known to have very low recall (Bos and Markert, 2005), so on-the-fly knowledge is crucial in this setting
clean_text: On PASCAL RTE datasets, strict logical inference is known to have very low recall (Bos and Markert, 2005), so on-the-fly knowledge is crucial in this setting.

citing_paper_authors: Ran, Tian | Yusuke, Miyao | Takuya, Matsuzaki
raw_text: Bos and Markert (2005) proposes features from a model builder; Raina et al (2005) proposes an abduction process; Tatu and Moldovan (2006) shows handcrafted rules could drastically improve the performance of a logic-based RTE system. As such, our current RTE system is at a proof of-concept stage, in that many of the above techniques are yet to be implemented
clean_text: Bos and Markert (2005) proposes features from a model builder; Raina et al (2005) proposes an abduction process; Tatu and Moldovan (2006) shows handcrafted rules could drastically improve the performance of a logic-based RTE system.

raw_text: NutCracker3 (Bos and Markert, 2005) is a system based on logical representation and automatic theorem proving, but utilize sonly WordNet (Fellbaum, 1998) as a lexical knowledge resource. Therefore, we provide our open-source textual entailment system, BIUTEE
clean_text: NutCracker (Bos and Markert, 2005) is a system based on logical representation and automatic theorem proving, but utilizes only WordNet (Fellbaum, 1998) as a lexical knowledge resource.
